title: Thesis on Catalyst Decentralized VC

f6_assessments.q0:
There is no doubt that a master's thesis whose theme focuses on Cardano is a real vote of confidence in the role we are playing as an alternative solution to the most pressing social, economic and environmental problems (plus all those that do not fall into these categories).  The proposal reveals a proposer in tune with that role.  A proposer who also wants to do his part.  However, a fair evaluation of the proposal requires a comparison with the Challenge in which it is enrolled. The fundamental motivation behind the "Challenge & Scouted for Students" Challenge, approved by the Catalyst community last fund, is to provide college and university students with a space completely separate from the regular Catalyst environment in which they can bring their projects to Project Catalyst and secure base funding, nothing financially ambitious. Clumsy projects, with flaws or weaknesses if any, but with a true innovative and creative student spirit, insolent and daring, that will lead their authors to find in our community a place to learn and get involved, a playground endowed not only with money, but more importantly, with the possibility to get hands on with the best technology in the industry while having access to the knowledge, experience and sense of collaboration of Catalyst members. A new concept for Catalyst no doubt, but an efficient one: in the student community of the planet lies that needle in the haystack that ends up changing the game we play so tightly with other blockchains and the legacy world, and it is our obligation to build the best of the magnets to find it. That's just what this Challenge is trying to do: build a suitable habitat for students, designed primarily by the students themselves. 

Because of my affinity with this Challenge (formal experience in education at school, university, company level) and my experience in Project Catalyst (actively participating in 90% of the community positions that exist: CA, VCA, Challenge Team member, funded proposer, involvement in multiple projects in Catalyst) I have been following it closely since it was approved at F8, because it never ceases to amaze me how often the scoreboard seeks to augment itself with topics of undeniable importance (Developer Ecosystem, Cross-Chain Collaboration, The Great Migration (From Ethereum)) to the point of discarding areas that in the real world have proven to be an inexhaustible source of ideas, creativity and results, such as those related to students. 

As an educator and experienced Project Catalyst member, I understand the intention behind the proposal and consider it completely valid. However, it is clear that it does not correspond to the purpose that the Community decided to support through this Challenge: neither the type of student who created the proposal, nor the objectives of the proposal are in line with the parameters of the Challenge.  I quote (excerpted from the Challenge information): "By creating a category of students and increasing exposure for their ideas, they can expect easier funding and to be scouted by engineers" (section What does success look like?). "Most student entrepreneurs suffer from a shortage of resources, especially when it comes to funding and hiring engineers" (Why is this important? section). "However, the number of proposals to Catalysts is increasing rapidly, and the community does not readily perceive small-scale proposals from students. .... Therefore, to make it easier for the community to recognize new ideas from students, we will establish a new category exclusively for students" (Challenge brief section). 

Taking into account the above reasoning, I must remove three stars from the final rating.
f6_assessments.q1: Although certainly general, the implementation plan and the budget correspond to the reality of the development of a thesis work.  The development of the thesis is a process characterized by its linearity.  The dizzying twists and turns involved in such academic work are rare. At the same time, it is an assurance of compliance that the proposal is directly linked to a key requirement in the proposer's professional life. The $10/hr rate assigned by the proposer to his work is indicative of someone who is not looking for anything beyond basic support to meet his objectives. I must reduce 1 star from the final rating because certainly more detail in the information provided at the level of implementation plan and budget would be desirable: it is a requirement in the presentation of any project to increase the level of detail of the procedures to be executed, this allows to know the dimensions of the project itself.
f6_assessments.q2: As someone who has made a career in formal education (school, university, company), I must say that the measurement tools provided by the proposal are not adequate.  An academic type project cannot be assigned the skin of a technical type project.  Peer review of an academic result is imperative.  Consequently, the fulfillment of the milestones described in the Feasability section are not a true indicator of the performance of the academic work: it is how the fruit of it is judged by the academic and technical community apt to judge it.  Therefore, I believe that better parameters for measuring the performance of the proposal should be developed, based on a deeper reflection of what it means to ask for support to develop an academic work as described in the proposal.  For the moment, I find that the proposal needs to strengthen its auditability conditions, which is why I must deduct three stars from the final rating.
f6_assessments.reply: While applauding the PA´s dedication to both formal education and Catalyst, it would appear he has a narrow interpretation of the Challenge setting as it was formulated. The excerpts presented under impact are true, however they only tell the technical side. I quote the first line of the Challenge: "Student entrepreneurs have exciting business ideas and motivations to start a business, but they lack the resources to implement them." An academic thesis laying out the case for student entrepreneurs to engage with Catalyst, in environments such as developing countries where funding is scarce, will help engage and onboard these students not only for this specific Challenge, but rather for the long run, increasing the value of Cardano as a whole by receiving their valuable projects and having them executed on-chain. Regarding auditability, the PA seems to have forgotten (or not read) that within the proposal, it is clearly stated that at the final stage, having first a rough then a final draft of the thesis, it is provided for "Community Engagement (both academic/university with fellow students and at developing country TownHalls)". This academic engagement amounts to what the PA has indicated as academic peer review, which of course is of vital importance to the adequate development of any academic product once in its latter stage of execution. Additionally, it would appear the PA is unfamiliar with the Reporting scheme that must be complied with as a funded proposer, which would surely alleviate his worries. I appeal to the vPAs reviewing this flag to filter out this assessment.

f6_assessments.q0: As a challenge centered in promoting student engagement and academic awareness of Cardano, this proposal addresses it twofold: firstly, as a proposal made by a student, it already demonstrates engagement from a university environment, and from a developing country no less; secondly, by proposing to write an academic thesis on Catalyst as an ideal VC funding mechanism for developing country student entrepreneurs, it promises to deliver a product that can be marketed and leveraged by the Cardano community with a seal of academic rigour in emerging market student entrepreneur networks.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer indicates that regardless of funding, he will of course need to write the thesis to graduate from the Masters program; therefore, it is highly likely that he will implement his proposal successfully, due to the necessary requirement of completing a thesis in order to graduate from an MSc university course. He also describes a concrete timeline, according to his university´s indications, with a detailed budget breakdown of the different stages to be dealt with, offering as well to handle translation into whichever language the community deems best suited for further marketability of the product.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer correctly states that, as a written product, the project´s progress will be determined by concrete milestones required by his university in the thesis submission procedure (Thesis Memorandum, First and succesive Chapters, Rough Draft and Final Draft), and correctly states that said progress can also be measured in terms of pages. Therefore, there should be no issue in fulfilling the reporting standards of the Cardano community once funding is approved. The fact that a third party, namely the university, has an independent schedule which must be fulfilled in order to present the thesis and graduate, is another element that adds to the certainty of auditability and verifiability of the progress and success of the proposal.
f6_assessments.reply: Thank you very much for your support, and I hope to be able to continue engaging with you and the rest of the community if the proposal is funded!

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal fits the challenge category perfectly because it encouraged the student to conduct and publish (thesis) a small study on how Catalyst VC alternative funding can be used to raise awareness of these opportunities in academic and business circles. As a consequence, the solution is an excellent way to raise awareness about the Cardano blockchain and Catalyst among young students, who are the most frequent adopters of novel technologies, providing an excellent potential to expand the ecosystem.By spreading awareness of these technologies in the academic world, the likelihood of conducting peer-reviewed research increases, which really is a key pillar of Cardano. The author also presumes that the outcome can be transferred into the local entrepreneurship network and thus have a larger impact on a larger scale. My recommendation for increased impact would be to try to publish the work in a peer-reviewed journal afterward on in close cooperation with knowledgeable academics, and to further spread the idea on researchgate and similar platforms to engage the academic spheres in the discussion.
f6_assessments.q1: For several reasons, I believe the project will be a success. First and foremost, the timeline is realistic, with 4-5 months planned for thesis writing and 3 months planned for community engagement to refine the work. Second, the execution of these should only be dependent on the student and his cooperation with his supervisor - thus I suspect it should be feasible without a doubt, but what I miss is maybe describing previous writing experience as well as the experience to conduct research, as well as some link or profile of the student - university profile/facebook or linkedIn.Finally, the budget appears to be reasonable in relation to the current challenge, which should encourage students and the community. Perhaps the budget should include an additional $2000 USD if they decide to refine the work and publish it in an open-access peer-reviewed academic journal. In my opinion it would add more value to the work.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs are not clearly defined, but the milestones are reasonable and largely dependent on the student's work. The proposer suggested the number of pages of distinct parts of the work as indicators of progress, which I don't think is a good measure of progress - it is well known that the discussion and introduction are the most difficult parts of the work and require significantly more time to proceed, whereas parts like method and so on are really easy to write and can be spread across more pages - thus number of pages is really a non-realiable indicator in my opinion.However, as suggested by the proposer, conducting interviews with the catalyst community may be a more feasible way to trace and refine the work. The delivery dates are set, and they most likely correspond to the university's internal deadline for completing the thesis.
f6_assessments.reply: Thank you very much for your support, and I hope to be able to continue engaging with you and the rest of the community if the proposal is funded!
